articles.headline: In Mass Shootings, Police Are Trained to ‘Confront the Attacker’
articles.snippet: As the Uvalde, Texas, massacre raises questions about the police response, experts describe complex, shifting circumstances. Speed, they say, is essential.
articles.abstract: As the Uvalde, Texas, massacre raises questions about the police response, experts describe complex, shifting circumstances. Speed, they say, is essential.
articles.lead_paragraph: Responding to a call of a mass shooting, police officers in the United States are trained, above all else, to stop the gunman. Act with urgency. Defend innocent lives.
articles.byline: By Jesus Jiménez, Shaila Dewan and Mike Baker

articles.headline: At N.R.A. Convention, the Blame Is on ‘Evil,’ Not Guns
articles.snippet: Above all else, activists and politicians at the gathering sought to divert pressure to support popular overhauls like expanded background checks by seizing on the issue of school safety.
articles.abstract: Above all else, activists and politicians at the gathering sought to divert pressure to support popular overhauls like expanded background checks by seizing on the issue of school safety.
articles.lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — One by one, the gun rights activists and politicians who showed up at the National Rifle Association convention on Friday said they were appalled, horrified and shaken by the massacre of 19 children and two adults a few days earlier in Uvalde, Texas.

articles.headline: Illegal Immigration Is Down, Changing the Face of California Farms
articles.snippet: Farmers are turning to workers on seasonal visas and mechanizing what they can. Many labor-intensive crops are shifting south of the border.
articles.abstract: Farmers are turning to workers on seasonal visas and mechanizing what they can. Many labor-intensive crops are shifting south of the border.
articles.lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.
articles.byline: By Eduardo Porter and Ryan Christopher Jones

articles.headline: Drones. Crutches. Potatoes. Russians Crowdfund Their Army.
articles.snippet: A grass-roots movement to get basic supplies to soldiers fighting in Ukraine reflects the growing recognition among Russians that their military was unprepared for major conflict.
articles.abstract: A grass-roots movement to get basic supplies to soldiers fighting in Ukraine reflects the growing recognition among Russians that their military was unprepared for major conflict.
articles.lead_paragraph: Natalia Abiyeva is a real-estate agent specializing in rental apartments in the city of Nizhny Novgorod, east of Moscow. But lately, she has been learning a lot about battlefield medicine.

articles.headline: Times Square at Its Overcrowded, Dizzying Worst Is Exactly What N.Y.C. Needs
articles.snippet: The economic future of New York depends on everyone coming back, not just the tourists. Too bad office workers don’t want to join them.
articles.abstract: The economic future of New York depends on everyone coming back, not just the tourists. Too bad office workers don’t want to join them.
articles.lead_paragraph: The sensory-overloaded tower will offer visitors the chance to do quite a lot, all in one place: They will be able to sing along with a hologram of their favorite pop star, spend their cryptocurrency, marvel at ever-changing digital art on the walls and dine on a 10,000-square-foot outdoor terrace. It will be an enviable perch to gaze out at Times Square, a neighborhood that before the pandemic represented 15 percent of the city’s economic output in just 0.1 percent of the land area.
articles.byline: By Nicole Hong and Jeenah Moon

articles.headline: Gun in Texas Shooting Came From Company Known for Pushing Boundaries
articles.snippet: Daniel Defense, which makes military-style rifles, was an early adopter of direct-to-consumer marketing and has a history of running provocative ads.
articles.abstract: Daniel Defense, which makes military-style rifles, was an early adopter of direct-to-consumer marketing and has a history of running provocative ads.
articles.lead_paragraph: After one of its military-style rifles was used in the Texas elementary school shooting on Tuesday, the gun manufacturer Daniel Defense published a pop-up statement on its home page sending “thoughts and prayers” to the community of Uvalde, Texas, and pledging to cooperate with the authorities.
articles.byline: By David Yaffe-Bellany and Jessica Silver-Greenberg

articles.headline: Massacres Test Whether Washington Can Move Beyond Paralysis
articles.snippet: The United States is facing a widening gap between the scale of gun violence and what America’s political leaders can agree are the right responses to the carnage.
articles.abstract: The United States is facing a widening gap between the scale of gun violence and what America’s political leaders can agree are the right responses to the carnage.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Days after 19 children and two teachers were gunned down in Texas, politicians in Washington are tinkering around the edges of America’s gun laws.

articles.headline: What Lia Thomas Could Mean for Women’s Elite Sports
articles.snippet: Although the number of top transgender athletes is small, the disagreements are profound, cutting to the core of the debate around gender identity and biological sex.
articles.abstract: Although the number of top transgender athletes is small, the disagreements are profound, cutting to the core of the debate around gender identity and biological sex.
articles.lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — The women on the Princeton University swim team spoke of collective frustration edging into anger. They had watched Lia Thomas, a transgender woman who swam for the University of Pennsylvania, win meet after meet, beating Olympians and breaking records.

articles.headline: Can Paramount Go It Alone?
articles.snippet: The dominance of Netflix and Disney in streaming has forced many companies to join forces. So far, Paramount has gone its own way.
articles.abstract: The dominance of Netflix and Disney in streaming has forced many companies to join forces. So far, Paramount has gone its own way.
articles.lead_paragraph: In January, the board of Paramount, including Shari Redstone, the company’s chair, met with a group of bankers to get an update on the media industry and to hear about potential deals that might help the company better compete with streaming giants like Netflix and Disney.

articles.headline: Apple Store Showdown: Inside the Battle for Union Representation
articles.snippet: Weary from the pandemic and pressured by inflation, retail employees of the tech giant are holding votes on whether to unionize.
articles.abstract: Weary from the pandemic and pressured by inflation, retail employees of the tech giant are holding votes on whether to unionize.
articles.lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — Sydney Rhodes’s frustration was rising. Seated at a hotel conference table across the street from the Apple store where she worked in Atlanta, she listened as her boss suggested to a dozen colleagues that they should be grateful to be paid more than other retail employees.

articles.headline: For NATO, Turkey Is a Disruptive Ally
articles.snippet: President Recep Tayyip Erdogan’s block on NATO membership for Sweden and Finland is likely to be managed, but Washington and the rest of the alliance are annoyed.
articles.abstract: President Recep Tayyip Erdogan’s block on NATO membership for Sweden and Finland is likely to be managed, but Washington and the rest of the alliance are annoyed.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When President Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey threatened this month to block NATO membership for Finland and Sweden, Western officials were exasperated — but not shocked.
articles.byline: By Michael Crowley and Steven Erlanger

articles.headline: From Sandy Hook to Uvalde, the Violent Images Never Seen
articles.snippet: Frustrated Americans ask whether the release of graphic photos of gun violence would lead to better policy. But which photos, and who decides?
articles.abstract: Frustrated Americans ask whether the release of graphic photos of gun violence would lead to better policy. But which photos, and who decides?
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — After Lenny Pozner’s six-year-old son Noah died at Sandy Hook, he briefly contemplated showing the world the damage an AR-15-style rifle did to his child.

articles.headline: A Church, a Gathering Place for Generations, Becomes a Hub for Uvalde’s Grief
articles.snippet: As soon as the scale of the tragedy became clear, congregants rushed to Sacred Heart Catholic Church. In the days since, they’ve kept coming in search of comfort and community.
articles.abstract: As soon as the scale of the tragedy became clear, congregants rushed to Sacred Heart Catholic Church. In the days since, they’ve kept coming in search of comfort and community.
articles.lead_paragraph: UVALDE, Texas — As word of the staggering death toll spread through Uvalde on Tuesday, the parishioners of Sacred Heart Catholic Church rushed, almost reflexively, to be together. Within an hour, they had filled the sanctuary for an impromptu Mass.

articles.headline: The Men Lost to 20 Bruckner Boulevard
articles.snippet: They were transforming a century-old Bronx ice house into a charter school. It became one of the deadliest construction sites in New York City in almost two decades.
articles.abstract: They were transforming a century-old Bronx ice house into a charter school. It became one of the deadliest construction sites in New York City in almost two decades.
articles.lead_paragraph: Two laborers board an elevator at the top of a five-story building under renovation in the Bronx. They wear construction helmets, reflective vests and face masks, none of which will do them any good.

articles.headline: Lawyer Who Plotted to Overturn Trump Loss Recruits Election Deniers to Watch Over the Vote
articles.snippet: A central figure in the scheme to reverse the 2020 election is mobilizing grass-roots activists into an “army of citizens” trained to aggressively monitor elections.
articles.abstract: A central figure in the scheme to reverse the 2020 election is mobilizing grass-roots activists into an “army of citizens” trained to aggressively monitor elections.
articles.lead_paragraph: In a hotel conference center outside Harrisburg, Pa., Cleta Mitchell, one of the key figures in a failed scheme to overturn Donald J. Trump’s defeat, was leading a seminar on “election integrity.”

articles.headline: Hit Hard by High Energy Costs, Hawaii Looks to the Sun
articles.snippet: The state is seeking to replace coal and oil with solar energy, aiming to rely extensively on rooftop panels on single-family homes.
articles.abstract: The state is seeking to replace coal and oil with solar energy, aiming to rely extensively on rooftop panels on single-family homes.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONOLULU — Toddi Nakagawa, who lives in a suburb of Honolulu, has spent years battling her family’s high electricity bills, which once topped $500 a month, by gradually buying more solar panels. After accumulating more than 70 panels and three stacks of batteries, she has gotten her family’s monthly bill down to just $26.
articles.byline: By Ivan Penn and Ruth Fremson
